repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - GEF/SADC Lake Malawi / Nyasa
            Biodiversity Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the project outcome as
            moderately satisfactory, with an unlikely sustainability,
            and modest institutional development impacts. Both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower are assessed
            unsatisfactory, given the poor quality at entry, conducive
            to critical failures in the appraisal of management
            practices, and, the neglect in establishing an independent
            research advisory committee to oversee the project's
            science agenda, respectively. The lessons learned raise two
            major issues: a) how to ensure a balanced scientific
            research, and pro-active planning for resource management,
            and, b) how to achieve sustainable management of
            trans-boundary resources, given differing riparian
            interests, and incentives to participate. The balance
            between research, and planning appears to be primarily
            determined by the terms of reference of the project manager,
            and to a lesser extent, by the effectiveness of the steering
            committee. While undoubtedly, the project's
            science-bias caused a lack of focus on the planning, and
            resource management, a more generalist scientific approach
            would have improved the Lake's management plans, and, a
            well designed operational set-up would have achieved
            relevant objectives, with a greater inclusive, and riparian
            approach to a balanced biodiversity conservation. Bank
            efforts should facilitate regional institutions, and plan
            extensive consultations to coordinate riparian efforts,
            through free-standing projects to better support
            cross-boundary resource conservation, with objective
            management, and technical reviews, and carefully structured partnerships.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - SADC Lake Malawi / Nyasa
            Biodiversity Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory.
            Regardless of success, several lessons emerge. The absence
            of data on the Lake's biodiversity, and productive
            systems, justified research which, in parallel with
            on-the-job training towards building the riparian states
            institutional capacity, was conducted by highly academic,
            and scientific experts. This far sighted decision, provided
            a cadre of scientific personnel, who can now build upon the
            research undertaken, to manage the lake in the future.
            However, it is important to note that the project's
            institutional design stems from weak horizontal linkages
            with national institutions, a most relevant factor to
            scientific findings. These institutions, the Fisheries
            Department, Water Resources Department, and the University
            of Malawi, whose linkages most likely may not reduce the
            long-term impact of the project, may well delay the adequacy
            of the lake's management. Nonetheless, the
            establishment of an environmental monitoring program for the
            maintenance of ecosystems, was a major decision for riparian
            cooperation in the lake's resource management, for it
            lay the foundation to strengthen riparian capacity, in
            preparation of the next phase of the program. However, the
            project reinforces that insufficient preparation of project
            components affects, and delays implementation, for it forces
            management to determine factors whose suitability should
            have been set at appraisal. Likewise, ill defined
            implementing roles, and organizational requirements, should
            have been defined at project preparation.

5077704.majtheme: Rule of law,Environment and natural resource management

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Lake Malawi / Nyasa Biodiversity
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The South Africa Development Community
            (SADC) Malawi/Nyasa Biodiversity Conservation Project will
            assist the riparian states in creating the scientific,
            educational, and policy basis necessary for conserving the
            biological diversity of the Lake and its unique ecosystem.
            It will be done through the following specific activities:
            (a) building scientific capacity within the riparian
            countries to survey, study and monitor the Lake's
            biodiversity, identify threats, and provide recommendations
            for the Lake's management; (b) surveying and
            inventorying species, identifying critical habitats and
            biodiversity hotspots and recommending preliminary measures
            to demarcate and protect such areas; (c) identify pollution
            sources and measuring water quality at sites where human
            activities threaten biodiversity; (d) preparing a Strategic
            Plan for the Nankumba Peninsula and Lake Malawi National
            Park for eco-tourism development, consistent with the
            protection and conservation of the Lake's biodiversity;
            (e) preparing a comprehensive Biodiversity Map and
            Management Plan for Lake Malawi/Nyasa based on the
            information provided by the species, habitat, and water
            quality analyses; (f) increasing conservation awareness
            among the lakeshore population and regional and national
            policy makers, whose decisions regarding regional
            development have an impact on the Lake's ecosystem; and
            (g) reviewing the adequacy of existing national
            environmental legislation in Malawi, Mozambique and Tanzania
            and making appropriate legislative recommendations for
            revision and/or strengthening enforcement for the
            conservation of the Lake's biodiversity.
